description: Behaviour science & habit strategies knowledge base for HabitLedger

principles.name: Loss Aversion
principles.description: People feel the pain of losing something more strongly than the pleasure of gaining something of equal value. This can be leveraged to motivate consistent saving and discourage impulsive spending.
interventions: Frame savings as 'not losing money to future you' rather than gaining interest
Track and visualize what you'd lose by breaking your savings streak
Calculate and display the opportunity cost of impulse purchases
Set up alerts showing 'money saved' rather than 'money spent'
Create a 'regret journal' to record feelings after impulse buys

principles.name: Habit Loops (Cue → Routine → Reward)
principles.description: Habits follow a three-step pattern: a cue triggers a routine, which leads to a reward. To change habits, identify the cue and reward, then substitute a better routine.
interventions: Identify your impulse spending cues (time, place, emotion, people)
Replace bad routine: instead of food delivery when stressed, take a 5-minute walk
Link savings to existing habits: 'After morning coffee, transfer ₹100 to savings'
Create reward substitutes: track streak days and celebrate milestones
Change your environment to remove cues (delete shopping apps, avoid trigger locations)

principles.name: Commitment Devices
principles.description: Tools or strategies that lock you into good behavior by making it harder or costly to deviate from your goals. Pre-commitment helps overcome future temptation.
interventions: Set up automatic transfers to savings account on payday
Use apps that lock money away until a specific date or goal
Share your goal with a friend or family member for accountability
Pre-commit to spending limits: leave credit card at home before shopping
Schedule bill payments immediately after receiving income
Join a savings challenge or accountability group

principles.name: Temptation Bundling
principles.description: Pair an unpleasant but beneficial activity with something you enjoy. This makes the good habit more attractive and easier to maintain.
typical_triggers: Difficulty finding motivation for good habits
Viewing saving as a sacrifice or punishment
interventions: Allow yourself a favorite podcast only while reviewing your budget
Treat yourself to a nice tea/coffee while checking savings progress
Watch a favorite show only on 'no-spend' evenings at home
Listen to music you love while meal prepping (saves money on takeout)
Combine weekly budget check with a relaxing Sunday morning routine
Reward streak milestones with small, affordable treats (not spending sprees)

principles.name: Friction Reduction (Make Good Habits Easy)
principles.description: Reduce the steps, effort, or time required to perform a good habit. The easier something is, the more likely you are to do it consistently.
typical_triggers: Too many steps to pay bills
interventions: Set up automatic SIP or recurring deposit on payday
Use simple expense tracking apps or pre-made budget templates
Keep budget spreadsheet open and visible on your desktop
Pre-schedule bill payments to avoid late fees and decision fatigue
Simplify goals: 'Save ₹5000/month' instead of complex formulas
Enable one-click savings transfers in your banking app

principles.name: Friction Increase (Make Bad Habits Hard)
principles.description: Add steps, delays, or obstacles to undesirable behaviors. Making bad habits inconvenient reduces the likelihood of following through on impulses.
typical_triggers: Food delivery apps on phone home screen
interventions: Delete food delivery and shopping apps from your phone
Remove saved payment info from online shopping sites
Keep credit cards in a drawer, not in your wallet
Log out of shopping accounts after each use
Add a 24-hour waiting rule before any non-essential purchase
Unsubscribe from promotional emails and marketing notifications
Use cash for discretionary spending (requires ATM trip, adds friction)

principles.name: Default Effect
principles.description: People tend to stick with the default option. By changing defaults, you can guide behavior toward better financial decisions without requiring active choices.
typical_triggers: Need to make repeated financial decisions
Setting up new accounts or services
interventions: Set default savings: automatically transfer percentage of income to savings
Default to 'no' for optional purchases unless you actively decide 'yes'
Set your investment or retirement contribution to auto-increase annually
Make home-cooked meals your default dinner plan, eating out the exception
Default to packed lunch; buying lunch requires conscious decision
Auto-pay bills to make timely payment the default

principles.name: Micro-Habits (2-Minute Rule)
principles.description: Start with a habit so small it takes less than 2 minutes. Tiny habits are easier to start and build momentum for larger behavior change over time.
typical_triggers: Feeling overwhelmed by big financial goals
Lack of confidence in financial discipline
Need for quick wins to build motivation
interventions: Start by saving just ₹50 per day instead of a large monthly amount
Check your bank balance once a day for 2 minutes (builds awareness)
Write down one expense each evening (leads to full expense tracking)
Transfer ₹100 to savings immediately after reading this (instant action)
Delete one shopping app today (small step toward reducing temptation)
Review just one line item in your budget each day
Celebrate every small win: 'I chose water over a ₹200 coffee today'
